citation.article-title: Pragia fontium gen. nov., sp. nov. of the family Enterobacteriaceae, isolated from water.

p.s: Description of Pragia fontium sp. nov.
Pragia fontium (fon' ti. um. L.gen.pl. n. fontium from springs or fountains, because all but the most recently isolated strain were isolated from well water or from pipes carrying drinking water)
Strains conform to the definition of the genus Pragia.
Growth at 4, 22, and 37°C, but not at 42°C.
Small (diameter, approximately 0.5 mm) lactose-negative colonies are formed on MacConkey and nutrient agar media; nonhemolytic on sheep blood agar.
Most strains are methyl red positive; indole is not produced.
Negative reactions in tests for lysine and ornithine decarboxylases, arginine dihydrolase, o-nitrophenyl-β-D-galactopyranoside, sodium acetate, and Jordan tartrate.
Acid, but not gas, is produced from D-glucose.
Acid is produced from galactose but not from L-arabinose or L-rhamnose.
Other reactions are given in Table 2.
The G+C content of DNAs from five strains is 46 to 47 mol%.
Isolated form drinking water, with a single isolate from the stool of a healthy woman.
The type strain of P.fontium is strain DRL 20125 (=HG16=CNCTC Eb11/82=CCUG 18073=CDC 963-84).
It was isolated in 1976 from well water in the Frgdek-Mistek district of Czechoslovakia.
